questions.text: A soft friable extradural hematoma with a honeycomb appearance on autopsy is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Heat hematoma

 

Explanation:

 

Heat hematoma (also called burn hematoma) shows characteristic features that distinguish it from traumatic extradural hematoma. The defining features include a honeycomb appearance and friable consistency, which are the key diagnostic features. Heat hematoma is recognized as one of the artifacts found in bodies exposed to extreme heat.

 

Comparison with Traumatic EDH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy - While coagulopathy can affect clot formation, it doesn't produce the characteristic honeycomb appearance mentioned in the question. Coagulopathy-related bleeding typically lacks the specific pattern described.

 

Option C. Postmortem; blunt force - Postmortem blunt force wouldn't produce the described honeycomb appearance. Postmortem injuries show no vital reaction, and the blood doesn't typically form organized patterns.

 

Option D. Antemortem; blunt force - Traumatic extradural hematomas due to blunt force have a smooth, jelly-like appearance rather than the honeycomb, friable consistency described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat hematoma (EDH due to heat) has distinctive characteristics including honeycomb appearance, friable consistency, bilateral presentation, and ability to cross suture lines—all opposite to traumatic EDH features.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in the blood. A left shift of the curve indicates an increase in the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, resulting in more oxygen being bound to hemoglobin at a given PO2.

 

Increased HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which causes a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. This allows fetal hemoglobin to extract oxygen more efficiently from the mother's blood in the placenta, where the PO2 is lower than in the adult circulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Factors causing a right shift (decreased affinity for oxygen):

 

Option B. Raised 2,3 BPG: Increased levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate decrease hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option C. Acidosis: A decrease in blood pH (increased H⁺ concentration) reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D. Increased CO₂: Higher levels of carbon dioxide also decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

choices.text: Downregulation of CYP2C19
Downregulation of CYP2D6
Upregulation of CYP1A1
Downregulation of CYP2E1

questions.text: A patient of 45 year with history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel, However, she had another attack of stroke after 6 months. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Downregulation of CYP2C19


Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug used to prevent MI and stroke. The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient can be influenced by various factors, including genetic variations that affect drug metabolism.

 

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19. Genetic polymorphisms or downregulation of CYP2C19 can lead to reduced conversion of clopidogrel to its active form. This results in decreased antiplatelet activity and a higher risk of thrombotic events, such as stroke. Individuals with reduced function alleles of CYP2C19 are known as "poor metabolizers," and in these patients, clopidogrel may be less effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Downregulation of CYP2D6: While CYP2D6 is important for the metabolism of many drugs, it is not primarily responsible for the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2D6 would not significantly impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Option C. Upregulation of CYP1A1: CYP1A1 is not involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel. Its upregulation would not affect the activation of clopidogrel or its therapeutic efficacy.

 

Option D. Downregulation of CYP2E1: CYP2E1 is involved in the metabolism of ethanol and certain other drugs but does not play a significant role in the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2E1 would not impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient may be due to the downregulation of CYP2C19. This enzyme is crucial for converting clopidogrel into its active form, and its reduced activity can lead to decreased antiplatelet effects and increased risk of thrombotic events.

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

The structure marked in the image is the fibula's neck.

 

The common peroneal nerve supplies motor fibers to the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, including the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles, which evert the foot and plantarflex the ankle joint. It also provides sensory fibers to the skin over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.

 

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve can occur due to trauma or compression, and can result in weakness or paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as sensory loss over the affected area. Common peroneal nerve injuries can be treated with conservative measures such as physiotherapy or surgery in severe cases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve in the calf region. It is formed by branches from both the common peroneal and tibial nerves. The sural nerve provides sensation to the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot. It runs more distally in the leg and is not closely associated with the neck of the fibula.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is another major branch of the sciatic nerve. After the division of the sciatic nerve, the tibial nerve continues its course in the posterior compartment of the leg, supplying muscles there and then continuing into the foot. It is primarily responsible for plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion. The tibial nerve does not have a close relation with the neck of the fibula as it runs more medially in the leg.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh. It is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. This nerve is located in the anterior aspect of the thigh, far away from the neck of the fibula, and has no direct relation with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Common peroneal nerve (also known as common fibular nerve), a significant branch of the sciatic nerve, follows a course along the thigh's posterior compartment and wraps around the fibula's neck, making it susceptible to injury. After encircling the fibula, it splits into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves, which innervate the leg's lateral and anterior compartments and contribute sensory functions to parts of the foot.

questions.text: The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25

 

  • The replacement dose of hydrocortisone in adrenal insufficiency varies depending on the severity of the condition and the individual needs of the patient. However, the usual starting dose is 15-25 mg of hydrocortisone per day, divided into two or three doses.
  • For those with more severe adrenal insufficiency or during periods of stress, higher doses may be needed, up to 100-150 mg per day, also divided into two or three doses.
  • It is important to note that the replacement dose of hydrocortisone may need to be adjusted over time based on the patient's response to treatment and any changes in their medical condition. Therefore, patients with adrenal insufficiency should be regularly monitored by their healthcare provider to ensure they are receiving the appropriate dose of hydrocortisone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is 15-25 mg per day, divided into two or three doses to mimic the body's natural cortisol production. This dose may be adjusted based on individual patient needs and response to treatment.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve. The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in Opioid Substitution Therapy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine


Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST) is a treatment given during the maintenance phase of opioid dependence. The goal is to reduce the harm associated with opioid use, such as the risks of HIV, Hepatitis, and illegal activities related to drug procurement. In OST, opioids like buprenorphine or methadone are used to replace more harmful opioids like heroin or morphine. These substitutions help control withdrawal symptoms and prevent relapse while allowing the patient to live a more stable life. Buprenorphine, being a partial opioid agonist, is preferred because it reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms without the euphoric effects associated with other opioids, making it an effective substitute in OST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is not used in OST because it is not an opioid. It may be used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification but does not replace opioids during the maintenance phase.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist, meaning it blocks the effects of opioids rather than substituting them. It can be used in the maintenance phase of opioid dependence but is not part of OST because it does not substitute one opioid for another.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used primarily to reverse opioid overdose. It is not used in OST because it does not have the substitutive effects needed for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence.

 

Educational Objective:


Opioid Substitution Therapy involves replacing a harmful opioid with a safer opioid like oral buprenorphine or methadone during the maintenance phase of treatment.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

questions.text: Disclosure of the identity of a rape victim is protected under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Section 228A

 

Explanation:

 

Section 228A of the Indian Penal Code specifically deals with disclosing the identity of rape victims. This section prohibits the publication or broadcasting of a rape victim's name or any information that could reveal their identity. The offense is punishable with imprisonment of up to 2 years. This legal provision exists to protect the privacy, dignity, and safety of sexual assault survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (Section 292A): This section does not relate to protecting rape victim identities. The IPC sections dealing with sexual offenses are clearly enumerated, and 292A is not listed among the relevant provisions for victim protection.

 

Option C (Section 376A): Section 376 and its subsections deal with the sexual offenses themselves, specifically defining rape and its punishment. These sections address the criminal act rather than the protection of victim identity.

 

Option D (Section 225A): This section is not related to rape victims or identity protection. It does not appear in the compilation of sexual offense statutes in the IPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The above question is as per old laws. It is not applicable as per new laws.

questions.text: Which type of psoriasis is Von Zumbusch Disease associated with? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Generalized Pustular Psoriasis

 

  • Von Zumbusch's pustular psoriasis refers to generalized pustular psoriasis, a serious condition accompanied by constitutional symptoms including high fever, chills, and tachypnea.
  • It is characterized by generalized fiery red erythema followed by the appearance of tiny waves of superficial pustules.

 

 

 

  • These pustules become confluent to form circinate lesions and lakes of pus.
  • As old pustules crust, new pustules continue to appear.
  • Precipitating factors include irritant effects of topical therapy and withdrawal of topical or systemic steroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Localized Pustular Psoriasis - This is incorrect 

 

  • Von Zumbusch refers specifically to the generalized form, not localized pustular psoriasis. Localized pustular psoriasis typically affects palms and soles and doesn't present with the systemic symptoms’ characteristic of Von Zumbusch.

 

 

Option C. Generalized Pustular Psoriasis of Pregnancy - This is incorrect 

 

  • Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy is specifically referred to as Impetigo Herpetiformis, not Von Zumbusch disease. 
  • While both are forms of generalized pustular psoriasis, they are distinct clinical entities.

 

Option D. Generalized Annular Pustular Psoriasis - This terminology is incorrect. 

 

  • While generalized pustular psoriasis may form circinate (circular) lesions, "Generalized Annular Pustular Psoriasis" is not a recognized distinct clinical entity in dermatology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Von Zumbusch pustular psoriasis is a severe form of generalized pustular psoriasis characterized by waves of superficial pustules on fiery red skin with associated systemic symptoms, often precipitated by steroid withdrawal or irritant topical therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution 

 

The standardized age mortality ratio serves as an indicator for the population's mortality rate adjusted to a standardized age distribution.

 

Standardization of Death Rates

 

  • While comparison of death rates of two populations, ‘crude death rate is not the right yardstick’, as age-compositions are different
  • Age-adjustment or age-standardization removes confounding effect of different age structures
  • Standardization may be direct or indirect
  • Standardization is carried out beginning by using a ‘Standard Population’

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution: Incorrect. Standardization typically adjusts for age, not sex.

 

Option C. Removal of bias due to different age group populations in different countries: Incorrect. This describes the purpose of age standardization, not the definition of standardized age mortality ratio.

 

Option D. To eliminate age structure of different countries: Incorrect. Age standardization accounts for, but does not eliminate, age structure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.

 

Additional Information

 

Types of Standardized Death Rates

 

Direct standardization:

 

  • Method:
    • Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied 
    • on a standard population
    • Total expected deaths calculated
    • Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • Feasibility:
    • Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
    • Availability of population in each age group

 

Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form

 

  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • Examples of indirect Standardization:

  • Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100

  • Life Table Analysis

  • Survival Analysis

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of respiratory depression and is suspected of having overdosed on opioids. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

In a patient presenting with symptoms of respiratory depression suspected to be due to an opioid overdose, the immediate next step in management should be the administration of Naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression. It acts quickly and is typically administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or via nasal spray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naltrexone: While Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is used primarily for the long-term management of alcohol and opioid dependence, rather than for the acute reversal of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in the treatment of opioid dependence. It is not suitable for the immediate treatment of opioid overdose and its respiratory depressant effects.

 

Option D. Methadone: Methadone is a long-acting opioid used in the maintenance treatment of opioid dependence and chronic pain management. It is not used for the treatment of acute opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of suspected opioid overdose, particularly with signs of respiratory depression, the administration of Naloxone is the immediate and appropriate intervention. Naloxone acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations
It is an anti-craving drug for alcohol
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists maximum up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body due to its inhibition of the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. This leads to a range of unpleasant symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, which are part of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. This reaction is intentional and serves as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It is given at a dose of 250mg/day, dose may be increased up to 500 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disulfiram is not primarily an anti-craving drug for alcohol. It works by creating an aversive reaction to alcohol rather than reducing the craving for alcohol. Medications like naltrexone or acamprosate are more accurately described as anti-craving drugs.

 

Option C. Disulfiram should be prescribed to highly motivated individuals. It requires a commitment to abstain from alcohol due to the serious nature of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. It is not typically recommended for individuals who are minimally motivated or likely to continue consuming alcohol.

 

Option D. The action of Disulfiram can persist beyond 2-3 days after stopping the drug. Its inhibitory effect on acetaldehyde dehydrogenase can last for up to a week or more in some cases, making it possible for the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction to occur even several days after the last dose of Disulfiram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes a severe and unpleasant reaction due to the accumulation of acetaldehyde, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, serving as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It should be used in highly motivated individuals committed to abstaining from alcohol.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

 

Explanation

 

PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Countercurrent system has two divisions:

 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.

 

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

 

  1. Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.

 

Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.

 

Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following phases of a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase 3

 

Phase 3 of a clinical trial is often referred to as an efficacy trial. This is because phase 3 trials are designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger and more diverse patient population. Phase 3 trials typically involve several hundred to several thousand participants and are usually randomized, controlled trials that compare the investigational drug or intervention to either a placebo or an active comparator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 1 trials are typically the first-in-human studies and are designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of the investigational drug or intervention.

 

Option B. Phase 2 trials are designed to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in phase 1 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 4 trials, also known as post-marketing surveillance studies, are conducted after a drug or intervention has been approved by regulatory agencies and are designed to monitor the long-term safety and effectiveness of the drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in earlier phases of the trial.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

This term specifically refers to the process of bringing repressed traumatic experiences to consciousness, accompanied by the appropriate emotional response, often leading to relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catharsis: This is a broader term for the release of emotional tension and can occur without specifically reliving a traumatic event.

 

Option C. Venting out: This generally means expressing feelings, especially of anger or frustration, but doesn't necessarily imply working through repressed trauma.

 

Option D. Guided relaxation: This involves being led (usually verbally) to a state of relaxation, and is not directly related to processing repressed emotions.

 

Therefore, "abreaction" best describes the conscious reliving of a painful, repressed experience and the subsequent emotional discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In abreaction, an attempt is made to bring the unconscious memories and emotions into conscious awareness using hypnosis, medications and other techniques.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 860.

choices.text: Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation

questions.text: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for the shorter bedaquiline regimen in the treatment of tuberculosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive TB

 

The shorter bedaquiline regimen is specifically designed for treating certain cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis. It is typically indicated in cases of Rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis or multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis under certain conditions. This regimen is used when the tuberculosis strain is resistant to Rifampicin, but it remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.

 

Additionally, in cases where there is resistance to Isoniazid (INH), the shorter regimen can be used if the resistance is due to a mutation in either the KatG or inhA gene, but not both.

 

If both mutations are present, or if the TB is severe or extrapulmonary, the shorter regimen is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary TB like Tubercular meningitis: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for extrapulmonary TB, as it is intended for pulmonary TB only. Extrapulmonary TB often requires a longer and more complex treatment regimen.

 

Option B. Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation: This scenario represents a more complex form of MDR-TB where resistance occurs due to mutations in both the KatG and inhA genes. The presence of both mutations generally excludes the use of the shorter regimen, as a longer and more intensive treatment is required.

 

Option C. Rifampicin-sensitive TB: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for Rifampicin-sensitive TB. This regimen is specifically designed for drug-resistant cases, particularly those resistant to Rifampicin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline shorter regimen is indicated for the treatment of -

 

  • Rifampicin-resistant TB (FQ sensitive) or MDR TB
  • INH Resistant TB – due to mutation in either inhA or Kat G gene (NOT BOTH)
  • Pulmonary TB

choices.text: Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).

 

Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be forcefully expired after forceful inspiration


            = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + Expiratory reserve volume
 

 

Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV

 

Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration: Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

 

Option B. Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration: Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.

 

Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: Incorrect, this combination describes the inspiratory capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

choices.text: Causes monofollicular development
Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH
Causes endometrial thinning
Can be used with gonadotropins

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding clomiphene citrate? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Causes monofollicular development
 

  • Clomiphene citrate is SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) that inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which in turn leads to an increase in LH/FSH, and this helps in the development of multiple follicles in the ovary. Clomiphene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility.
  • Due to its anti-estrogenic action over the endometrium, it causes thickening of the cervical mucus and thinning of the endometrium.
  • Sometimes for ovulation induction, gonadotropins can be used with clomiphene, but it has a risk of giving rise to multiple pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomerulus

 

The above histology image shows the glomerulus of a nephron.

 

Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries located within Bowman's capsule in the renal cortex of the kidney. Here are the key histological features of the glomerulus:

 

  • Capillary Endothelium: The innermost layer of the glomerulus consists of fenestrated endothelial cells. These fenestrations or pores allow plasma (minus the larger proteins) to move from the blood into Bowman's space.
  • Basement Membrane: Surrounding the endothelial cells is the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is a specialized extracellular matrix made up of type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins. The GBM serves as a filter, preventing the passage of large proteins and cells but allowing smaller molecules to pass through.
  • Podocytes: These specialized epithelial cells cover the outer surface of the glomerular capillaries. They have foot processes called "pedicels" which interdigitate with one another, leaving filtration slits between them. The slit diaphragm, formed by intercellular junctions between adjacent pedicels, provides an additional barrier to the filtration of plasma proteins.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillaries of the glomerulus, mesangial cells have phagocytic activity and help in the structural support of the capillaries. They can also contract, thus regulating the blood flow through the glomerulus. Additionally, mesangial cells produce extracellular matrix components.
  • Juxtaglomerular Cells: These specialized smooth muscle cells are found in the afferent arteriole at the point of entry into the glomerulus. They secrete renin, a crucial enzyme in the renin-angiotensin system which regulates blood pressure.
  • Macula Densa: Although not a part of the glomerulus, the macula densa is closely related. It is a group of tall, closely packed cells in the distal convoluted tubule that detect changes in the sodium chloride levels in the filtrate and communicate with the juxtaglomerular cells to regulate renin secretion.
  • Bowman's Capsule: This is a double-layered capsule that surrounds the glomerulus. The inner layer, or visceral layer, is composed of podocytes. The outer layer, or parietal layer, is made up of a simple squamous epithelium. Between these two layers is the Bowman's space, into which the filtrate from the blood accumulates before moving into the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig Cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

 

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between.

 

Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function.The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells

 

 

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

 

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

﻿﻿ The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

 

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

 

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans

 

 

Option C: The thymic medulla contains fewer lymphocytes than the cortex, and the epithelial cells (E) located here have different morphology and function. The most characteristic feature of the medulla in humans is the presence of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles (H). These are of variable size and contain aggregates of thymic epithelial cells releasing many cytokines important within the medullary microenvironment, especially for dendritic cell activity and for the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glomerulus consists of a network of capillaries encased within Bowman's capsule, playing a key role in blood filtration.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text:
A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Ram is the index case
  2. Shyam is primary case
  3. Ram got infected from Shyam
  4. If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All are correct

 

Index case: The first case that comes to the notice of the investigator. In this situation, Ram is the index case as he is the one presented to the clinic first.

 

Primary case: The first case of a disease in a population. Shyam, who exhibited symptoms a few days earlier, is the primary case.

 

Transmission: Given the incubation period of measles (7 to 18 days), it is likely that Ram got infected from Shyam, who was in an infectious state.

 

Post-exposure prophylaxis: If the mother had reported Shyam's infection, Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis. This can be in the form of a measles vaccine within 72 hours of exposure or immunoglobulin up to 6 days post-exposure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.

choices.text: Heparan sulfate
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

 

Explanation

 

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibronectin: While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.

 

Option C. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.

 

Option D. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for delusional disorder?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

This is not a typical risk factor for delusional disorder. It usually starts in middle or late adult life.

 

Other Options:

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle or late adult life, and it is uncommon in young individuals.

 

Option A. Recent immigration: True. Recent immigration or cultural isolation can be associated with the development of certain types of delusions.

 

Option B. Social isolation: True. Individuals who are socially isolated are at increased risk for the development of delusional disorder.

 

Option C. Family history: True. Having a family history of delusional disorder can increase the risk of developing the condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle to late adulthood. It is characterized by development of a single delusion or a set of related delusions, which are usually persistent and sometimes are life long.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 331.

questions.text:
Examine the list of features given: [INICET MAY 2024]

 

  1. Delayed skin pinch
  2. Lethargy
  3. Thirst
  4. Sunken eyes
  5. Reduced Urine output

 

The features of some dehydration include:
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 3, 4

 

According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three types: no dehydration, some dehydration, and severe dehydration.

 

  • Some Dehydration: This condition is diagnosed when there are at least two of the following four signs: thirst, sunken eyes, delayed skin pinch (skin pinch goes back slowly), and restlessness or irritability. These signs indicate a moderate level of dehydration where the body is starting to show physical symptoms, but it has not yet progressed to a severe state.
  • In the question:
    • Delayed skin pinch (option 1) is one of the signs.
    • Thirst (option 3) is another sign.
    • Sunken eyes (option 4) is also a recognized sign of some dehydration.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option B, which includes all the relevant features (1, 3, and 4).

 

Other Options:

 

2: Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three levels based on specific signs and symptoms:

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

 

  • The structure that is most likely damaged to result in severe watery diarrhea resembling rice gruel stool is the Zona Occludens.
  • Zona Occludens, also known as Tight Junctions, are specialized intercellular junctions between epithelial cells that regulate the movement of substances across the intestinal wall. They are located at the apical end of the lateral membrane of adjacent epithelial cells and are responsible for maintaining the integrity and impermeability of the intestinal barrier.
  • Damage to the Zona Occludens can result in increased permeability of the intestinal barrier, leading to the leakage of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is often seen in infectious diarrhea caused by bacterial or viral pathogens that can damage the tight junctions, leading to increased intestinal permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gap Junction: Incorrect. Gap junctions are involved in cell-cell communication and the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells, but they are not directly involved in regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option C. Adherent Junction: Incorrect. Adherent junctions are involved in maintaining cell-cell adhesion but are not primarily responsible for regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Incorrect. Hemidesmosomes are involved in cell-matrix adhesion and do not play a role in the regulation of intestinal permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:
